title: Green Hammerton Walks

images.title: Mtaylor848, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Green Hammerton village scene.

images.title: John S Turner / Green Hammerton Independent Chapel/St Joseph's RC Church
images.caption: St Joseph's Roman Catholic church, Green Hammerton, North Yorkshire. Built in 1797 as an Independent chapel, redundant in 1960, and converted into a Roman Catholic church in 1961

images.title: Stephen McKay / Green Hammerton
images.caption: Looking along York Road. The building on the immediate left is the Green Hammerton Reading Room - a community hall run by the Green Hammerton Recreational Charity which also runs the village playing fields. There are plans to demolish the Reading Room and replace it with a modern facility in a different location. Further along the street the post office on the left and the Bay Horse on the right can be seen.

images.title: The Bay Horse, Green Hammerton by Ian S, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Bay Horse, Green Hammerton

images.title: Gordon Hatton / The Green [south end]
images.caption: The Green [south end]. It's appropriate that Green Hammerton should have a village green. This is the south end where it meets the main street through the village.

images.title: Station Road, Kirk Hammerton by David Dixon, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Station Road, Kirk Hammerton

images.title: David Rogers / The Old Fire Station
images.caption: The Old Fire Station. On Kirk Hammerton Lane.

images.title: Frank Glover / The Old Mill
images.caption: This old mill, at Mill Farm, sits next to the River Nidd, just south of Kirk Hammerton.

description: This village is located in the Harrogate district of North Yorkshire. The rural village can be reached by rail on the Harrogate line which runs from Leeds to York via Knaresborough and Harrogate. Local walking highlights include the neighbouring village of Nun Monkton and the historic Beningbrough Hall. Nun Monkton is located just a few miles to the east at the confluence of the Rivers Ouse and River Nidd. On the opposite side of the river there's the 18th century hall with its beautiful grounds and gardens. This little walk from the village follows a country lane south to visit neighbouring Kirk Hammerton. On the way there's nice views of the surrounding countryside and a visit to the River Nidd which flows just to the south of the village.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Bay Horse is a fine place for some post walk refreshments. They serve good quality home cooked food and also provide rooms if you'd like to stay in the area. Inside there's a cosy real fire with a pleasant garden area for warmer days. The inn is dog friendly.

display_address: Cowley Mews, Green Hammerton, North Yorkshire, York and North Yorkshire, England, YO26 8HF, United Kingdom
